title: Matthew Adam Turner, PhD
text:
I work to contribute to the emerging science of understanding how populations of individuals collectively adapt to their social and physical environment through exploratory learning, social influence, and evolution. Wise collective adaptation is essential for mitigating risk of disaster caused by climate change, global pandemics, or other threats. I develop mechanistic models of how collective adaptation in society emerges from individual- and group-level behavior. Mechanistic models can be used to computationally test the logic of potential hypotheses about how collective adaptation emerges, or to explain emergent collective adaptation in empirical data. What we learn from this can be combined to form a rigorous understanding of collective adaptation. This rigorous understanding can be used to design wiser collective action. To learn more, please see some of my primary works below.My blog collects research notes and tutorials on how I contribute to (the RUCA Blog). My CV contains more about me.



Turner, M. A., Singleton, A. L., Harris, M. J., Harryman, I., Lopez, C. A., Arthur, R. F., Muraida, C., & Jones, J. H. (2023). Minority-group incubators and majority-group reservoirs support the diffusion of climate change adaptations. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences. https://doi.org/10.1098/rstb.2022.0401



I am currently a Pandemic Preparedness Postdoctoral Scholar working in James Holland Jones’ Human Evolutionary Ecology and Health group in the Social Sciences Division of the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability at Stanford University. Before I received my PhD in Cognitive and Information Sciences from the University of California, Merced, I received an MS in Applied Physics from Rice University and worked professionally as a data engineer and lead research software developer.

title: The RUCA Blog
text:
Collective adaptation is the phenomenon where individuals in a population change or evolve in such a way that characteristics of the entire population change with the goal of increased fitness, which could mean increased survival, happiness, resources, or similar things that could be perceived as good (Galesic et al. 2023). This definition is abstract by design, since collective action could occur in human, non-human animal, simple or single-cell organism, or virus populations. Changes are not always beneficial, however, such as if myopic increases in consumption in times of temporary surplus lead to overconsumption and long-term decline. Humans are unique in our ability to develop and evolve cultural adaptations that can facilitate adaptation much more rapidly than genetic evolution can. However, our capacity for culture, and the cognitive social learning capacities that enable culture, evolved genetically, including conversational turn-taking, joint attention, and predictive processing which can be used for social or asocial, trial-and-error learning.
These blog posts explore what components, mechanisms and resulting processes underlie collective adaptation. These posts also explore how to advance the theory of collective adaptation through mechanistic modeling via agent-based or other approaches.

title: Matthew Adam Turner, PhD
text:
Hello and welcome! I am currently a Pandemic Preparedness Postdoctoral Scholar working in James Holland Jones’ Human Evolutionary Ecology and Health group in the Social Sciences Division of the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability at Stanford University.
I received my PhD in Cognitive and Information Sciences from the University of California, Merced. I have an MS degree in Applied Physics from Rice University, and a dual BS degree in Mathematics and Physics from Syracuse University. I worked professionally in Moscow, Idaho, as a data engineer at an economic modeling firm and then as a lead research software developer at the University of Idaho working on a tristate (Idaho, Nevada, New Mexico) model- and data-intensive hydrology project.

title: Intro to a rigorous understanding of collective adaptation
text:
What is a rigorous understanding of collective adaptation and why do we need it?
Our current epoch is characterized by threats of climate change, ecosystem loss, pandemics, and malicious use of artificial intelligence and associated technologies. In response, we humans are challenged to collectively develop adaptations that mitigate or prevent greater catastrophe [@PisorLansingMagargal2023,@Currie2024]. Collective adaptation is an emergent phenomena composed of constituent sub-processes occurring across several time, population, and geographic/spatial scales: from milliseconds to millenia; from an individual to dyads to the global metapopulation; and from micrometers-long neurons to global-scale communication networks [@GalesicEtAl2023].


A rigorous understanding of collective adaptation via mechanistic modeling
Mechanistic models are useful for emergent phenomena such as collective adaptation because they force experimenters to explicitly state what parts of their system of interest. A study of the development of useful mechanistic models reveals that models must be properly shielded in a way that makes empirical sense.
